#Text=Exclusive interview with prominent blogger , David Farrar
#Text=Thursday , May 10 , 2007

#Text=Freelance journalist writing for Wikinews , Gabriel Pollard , with help from Brian Anderton , has interviewed New Zealand-based blogger , David Farrar on blogging , web 2.0 , and the Internet in general .
#Text=David Farrar is most known for his " fairly popular " blog , Kiwiblog , where he posts on various topics , including politics and technology .

column1: #Text=He is the vice-president of the Internet Society of New Zealand , and has been involved in helping to split Telecom New Zealand up and in anti-spam legislation .
#Text=David Farrar first started using the " best invention ever , " Internet , in February 1996 after having owned a BBC Micro microcomputer since 1982 .
#Text=On the Internet he debated various issues using Usenet newsgroups .
#Text=Kiwiblog now serves for this purpose .
#Text=He then got his own personal Internet account with ihug in August of that year .
#Text=Farrar also has political ties , which can be seen in some of his blog posts .

#Text=For eight years , Farrar worked for various Prime Ministers ( PM ) and Opposition leaders for the National Party , working with the likes of former PM Jim Bolger and former PM Jenny Shipley in the Media Services Unit of Ministerial Services .

#Text=Until Farrar landed himself a job in parliament , he had been using mainly Apple computers , " [ I ] finally converted to Microsoft in 1997 after being the only person in Parliament to have a Mac ! "
#Text=Farrar was involved with introducing public e-mail for ministers , and the first Prime Minister website .
#Text=In 2004 , after leaving politics , Farrar set up his polling and research company .
#Text=Kiwiblog , sparked by now defunct blog NZ Pundit by Gordon King , currently receives over 300,000 visitors a month .
#Text=He suspects that Russell Brown , and the Spareroom blogs get well over 100,000 visitors .
#Text=" There ’s then probably a dozen or so other bloggers who get into the tens of thousands . "

#Text=" Gordon [ King ] would post wonderful polemics challenging the conventional thinking and reporting , and after a few months of reading him I realized that I also had views and could try sharing them with the world .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=Farrar admits to not having a deliberate strategy for promoting himself and his blog , he just found that doing more posts in a day and posting what he was interested in got the visitors that were interested in the same things .

_	_	_	_

#Text=Oh and most important of all is to have a sense of humour and enjoy doing it .

_	_	_	_

#Text=If Farrar was n't blogging , he says he would be  Earning money !

#Text=However it is doing well enough that I can divide my time up between my business , InternetNZ and blogging and not starve .

_	_	_	_

#Text=Farrar has a few tips for those politicians who have started a blog , or are looking at starting one up ,  Very few are successful because [ they ] treat it as a one way communication tool where they just post press releases or travel diaries .

#Text=John Key is video blogging and responding to comments through future videos , which is a different way to interact .

_	_	_	_

#Text=But still warns that most readers of blog prefer  honest opinion " instead of reading what the politicians want them to read .

column1: #Text=Farrar is a huge supporter of Wikipedia and says that he uses it multiples times a day .
#Text=He says that he was " very proud " when the Wikipedia community regarded him as notable enough to have his own entry .
#Text=" I wish I had more time to edit Wikipedia .

#Text=Farrar says the success to websites such as Wikipedia and YouTube is because of multiple user generated content ,  ... rather than tightly controlled content from one source . "

column1: #Text=The focus on the community at large is also a major factor of their success .
#Text=When asked where he sees the Internet in decades from now , his simple response was , " I wish I knew . "
#Text=But he does predict every house in New Zealand will be connected to the Internet via fibre optics .

#Text=One scenario Farrar drew was , " ... being able to see a map of your local area on your phone , and not just get told where the nearest toilets or bookstore is , but also if any of your friends are nearby . "
#Text=David Farrar would just like to say thanks for the opportunity of being interviewed on Wikinews .
#Text=Blogs he 's most addicted to
#Text=David Farrar
#Text=subscribes to literally hundreds of blogs , below are the ones he 's most addicted to .
#Text=Cactus Kate on men , sex and politics .
#Text=Whale Oil is wonderfully offensive with some great multimedia .
#Text=Tony Milne on politics national and local .
#Text=Idiot/Savant is an encyclopedia of info on what is happening in Parliament and politics .
#Text=You get not just Russell Brown , but also David Slack , Keith Ng and many others .
#Text=A bunch of female Young Labour bloggers half on their sex lives and half on politics – the perfect mix .
#Text=Span gives a consistently challenging view of politics from a young female feminist and unionist perspective .
#Text=TUANZ ’s Downstream blog on what is happening in the telco industry .
#Text=Juha Saarinen - great stories on interesting things .
#Text=A great joint blog about my home town .
